Award.AwardTitle: RUI: NMR Crystallography and Weak Hydrogen Bonds
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this New Award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanisms Program supports Professor Manish A. Mehta of Oberlin College in a project involving investigations of a series of peptides using X-ray and neutron diffraction, quantum chemical calculations and solid-state NMR spectroscopy. A combination of modern NMR techniques will characterize the carbon-13 and nitrogen-15 chemical shift tensors in a series of four glycine-central and four alanine-central tripeptides, which span a range of molecular geometries. In addition, X-ray and neutron diffraction, solid-state NMR and computational chemistry will be used to investigate weak hydrogen bonds in a homologous series of three peptides. These investigations of molecules with known structure will place solid-state NMR data on a more rigorous footing and strengthen the links between NMR and crystallographic data sets.

This project, which includes collaborative activities with experts in X-ray diffraction, neutron scattering, and NMR spectroscopy, will provide valuable research experiences for Oberlin College undergraduates. The grant will support ongoing summer workshops for high school chemistry teachers in order to bring developments in modern spectroscopy to U.S. high school classrooms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With this grant, we have investigated the three-dimensional structure of a class of molecules called peptides, which may be thought of as miniature proteins. Using a variety of complementary spectroscopic methods, we determined the structure of different dipeptides and tripeptides in condensed phases. The state-of-the-art techniques included solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance, X-ray diffraction, and high-level numerical calculations. We established that the magnetic resonance frequency of the nuclei (called the chemical shift) can be used to extract fine structural information, which is otherwise difficult to discern. In one of the projects, we observed that different crystalline structures of a specific peptide (called polymorphs) may be generated via grinding, or mechanochemistry. In the course of our investigations, we have exploited the synergy between magnetic resonance and diffraction, an emerging area known as NMR Crystallography. Our work resulted in three publications in top tier peer-reviewed journals.

 

Research conducted under this RUI grant was driven entirely by undergraduates, ranging from rising sophomores to advanced seniors. They were involved at all stages, including the writing of the resulting manuscripts. Research experiences, such as those offered through this NSF grant, have served as a powerful vehicle to prepare future leaders in the chemical sciences – and that has been the work’s biggest broader impact. The grant has supported the work of Oberlin undergraduates during the academic year, Oberlin’s January winter term, and the summers. Since the start of my NSF support, eleven of my undergraduate research collaborators have gone on to top graduate programs in physical or biophysical chemistry at Columbia, MIT, Yale, Stanford, Duke, and Harvard, three of whom won an NSF Graduate Research Fellowship. The grant supported travel for students and me to attend various local, regional, and national conferences, where we presented our results. Undergraduate research experiences such as these give the students a competitive advantage on the scientific world stage, and, as such, they contribute to a key national interest.
